Can you really get hired from anywhere in the world?As I learnt, it's one of the toughest questions to answer in the recruitment world. Can you really get hired from anywhere in the world?As I learnt, it's one of the toughest questions to answer in the recruitment world. But many of these platforms require paid subscriptions to access job listings, creating a barrier for the unemployed, especially in developing countries.Imagine trying to apply for jobs when you can't even afford to unlock a post. It’s a harsh reality for those already struggling.𝑻𝒉𝒆 𝑰𝒓𝒐𝒏𝒚 𝒐𝒇 𝑨𝒄𝒄𝒆𝒔𝒔Remote work is supposed to be inclusive, yet paywalls create a digital divide. Can you really get hired from anywhere in the world?As I learnt, it's one of the toughest questions to answer in the recruitment world. The details are fuzzy, bias is always seeping into the supposedly fair assessment of equal employment opportunities (spoiler alert!), and we sort of... just roll with the punches in Africa.I enjoyed exploring this question with knowledgeable folks and wonderful community who shared their experiences with me, and pitched this story in the first place.Let's make Digital Nomads even better.I'm looking to explore more topical issues around housing, economy, and tech in African hubs and how nomads impact these different dimensions.Let's talk hashtag#Nomads; send a message.And oh—the answer to the question I opened with is more systemic and rather circumstantial than I'd imagined. Can you really get hired from anywhere in the world?As I learnt, it's one of the toughest questions to answer in the recruitment world. The details are fuzzy, bias is always seeping into the supposedly fair assessment of equal employment opportunities (spoiler alert!), and we sort of... just roll with the punches in Africa.I enjoyed exploring this question with knowledgeable folks and wonderful community who shared their experiences with me, and pitched this story in the first place.Let's make Digital Nomads even better.I'm looking to explore more topical issues around housing, economy, and tech in African hubs and how nomads impact these different dimensions.Let's talk hashtag#Nomads; send a message.And oh—the answer to the question I opened with is more systemic and rather circumstantial than I'd imagined. Can you really get hired from anywhere in the world?As I learnt, it's one of the toughest questions to answer in the recruitment world. Can you really get hired from anywhere in the world?As I learnt, it's one of the toughest questions to answer in the recruitment world. The details are fuzzy, bias is always seeping into the supposedly fair assessment of equal employment opportunities (spoiler alert!), and we sort of... just roll with the punches in Africa.I enjoyed exploring this question with knowledgeable folks and wonderful community who shared their experiences with me, and pitched this story in the first place.Let's make Digital Nomads even better.I'm looking to explore more topical issues around housing, economy, and tech in African hubs and how nomads impact these different dimensions.Let's talk hashtag#Nomads; send a message.And oh—the answer to the question I opened with is more systemic and rather circumstantial than I'd imagined. Can you really get hired from anywhere in the world?As I learnt, it's one of the toughest questions to answer in the recruitment world. The details are fuzzy, bias is always seeping into the supposedly fair assessment of equal employment opportunities (spoiler alert!), and we sort of... just roll with the punches in Africa.I enjoyed exploring this question with knowledgeable folks and wonderful community who shared their experiences with me, and pitched this story in the first place.Let's make Digital Nomads even better.I'm looking to explore more topical issues around housing, economy, and tech in African hubs and how nomads impact these different dimensions.Let's talk hashtag#Nomads; send a message.And oh—the answer to the question I opened with is more systemic and rather circumstantial than I'd imagined. What are the odds for Africans living and working from the continent?I talk about it here: https://lnkd.in/dRwmT3V7What's your experience with "location-adjusted" pay?

Can you really get hired from anywhere in the world?As I learnt, it's one of the toughest questions to answer in the recruitment world. The details are fuzzy, bias is always seeping into the supposedly fair assessment of equal employment opportunities (spoiler alert!), and we sort of... just roll with the punches in Africa.I enjoyed exploring this question with knowledgeable folks and wonderful community who shared their experiences with me, and pitched this story in the first place.Let's make Digital Nomads even better.I'm looking to explore more topical issues around housing, economy, and tech in African hubs and how nomads impact these different dimensions.Let's talk hashtag#Nomads; send a message.And oh—the answer to the question I opened with is more systemic and rather circumstantial than I'd imagined. What are the odds for Africans living and working from the continent?I talk about it here: https://lnkd.in/dRwmT3V7What's your experience with "location-adjusted" pay?

Can you really get hired from anywhere in the world?As I learnt, it's one of the toughest questions to answer in the recruitment world. The details are fuzzy, bias is always seeping into the supposedly fair assessment of equal employment opportunities (spoiler alert!), and we sort of... just roll with the punches in Africa.I enjoyed exploring this question with knowledgeable folks and wonderful community who shared their experiences with me, and pitched this story in the first place.Let's make Digital Nomads even better.I'm looking to explore more topical issues around housing, economy, and tech in African hubs and how nomads impact these different dimensions.Let's talk hashtag#Nomads; send a message.And oh—the answer to the question I opened with is more systemic and rather circumstantial than I'd imagined. 🚀 Level 3| Multithreaded Java Projects | Java Development Intern Cognifyz Internship Program Technologies 🧑‍💻As part of my internship journey Cognifyz Technologies, I explored the power of multithreading and synchronization in Java by building two mini-projects:🔐 1. MultiThreaded Bank Application: Simulates concurrent deposit and withdrawal operations on a shared bank account using ReentrantLock to ensure thread safety and data consistency.🎟 2. Ticket Booking System: Implements a simple synchronized method for booking tickets to prevent race conditions when multiple users try to book at the same time.💡 Key Concepts Applied: ✔️ Threading ✔️ Synchronization (synchronized, ReentrantLock) ✔️ Java OOP ✔️ Safe concurrent access to shared resourcesGrateful for the opportunity to apply core Java concepts in real-world scenarios! 🙌hashtag#Java hashtag#Multithreading hashtag#CognifyzTechnologies hashtag#Level3 hashtag#JavaInternship hashtag#ConcurrencyInJava hashtag#ThreadSafety hashtag#OOP hashtag#InternshipExperience hashtag#LearningByDoing hashtag#SoftwareDevelopment

Can you really get hired from anywhere in the world?As I learnt, it's one of the toughest questions to answer in the recruitment world. The details are fuzzy, bias is always seeping into the supposedly fair assessment of equal employment opportunities (spoiler alert!), and we sort of... just roll with the punches in Africa.I enjoyed exploring this question with knowledgeable folks and wonderful community who shared their experiences with me, and pitched this story in the first place.Let's make Digital Nomads even better.I'm looking to explore more topical issues around housing, economy, and tech in African hubs and how nomads impact these different dimensions.Let's talk hashtag#Nomads; send a message.And oh—the answer to the question I opened with is more systemic and rather circumstantial than I'd imagined. What are the odds for Africans living and working from the continent?I talk about it here: https://lnkd.in/dRwmT3V7What's your experience with "location-adjusted" pay?

Java 24: More than an update — a powerful step forward for modern software architecture. hashtag#LinkedInInsiderBRWith the official release of Java 24, Oracle continues to evolve the platform in ways that directly support today's demands for scalability, modularity, and cloud-native design. For professionals like me who architect systems with Hexagonal Architecture (DDD) and deploy on AWS, this release brings substantial benefits.🚀 Key Features in Java 24:✅ JEP 447 – Statements before super(...) Allows initialization logic before calling the superclass constructor. This enhances flexibility in rich domain models and simplifies base-class inheritance patterns in DDD.✅ JEP 456 – Unnamed Variables and Patterns (Preview) Reduces boilerplate when using pattern matching, making business logic cleaner and more expressive.✅ JEP 459 – String Templates (Second Preview) Provides safe and efficient string interpolation — ideal for building dynamic responses, configurations, and messages without complex concatenation.✅ JEP 460 – Vector API (7th Incubator) Enables data-parallel operations for better performance in compute-heavy tasks — relevant for analytics or event-driven systems.✅ JEP 462 – Structured Concurrency (Second Preview) Improves thread lifecycle management and simplifies parallel processing. This is huge for backend services needing concurrency without chaos — perfect fit for services deployed via AWS Lambda, ECS, or EKS.🧱 How this strengthens Hexagonal Architecture and DDDJava 24’s cleaner syntax and enhanced language constructs allow for: 🔹 Richer domain modeling without ceremony 🔹 Easier testing and mocking of application ports 🔹 Clearer separation of concerns in inbound/outbound adapters 🔹 Better observability and tracing when paired with AWS services like CloudWatch & X-Ray☁️ AWS + Java 24 = Cloud-native powerCombined with AWS, Java 24 enables: ✅ Lighter Lambda functions (faster cold starts with JDK optimizations) ✅ Enhanced developer productivity with CodeWhisperer and Amazon Q Developer ✅ Seamless integration with infrastructure-as-code (CDK, Terraform) and microservices ecosystemsWe’re not just writing code — we’re building resilient, scalable ecosystems. Java 24 gives us sharper tools to do that smarter, faster, and cleaner.Are you already experimenting with Java 24? What’s your favorite improvement so far?hashtag#Java24 hashtag#HexagonalArchitecture hashtag#DDD hashtag#SoftwareArchitecture hashtag#AWS hashtag#CloudNative hashtag#Innovation hashtag#BackendEngineering hashtag#Leadership hashtag#LinkedInInsiderBR

Can you really get hired from anywhere in the world?As I learnt, it's one of the toughest questions to answer in the recruitment world. The details are fuzzy, bias is always seeping into the supposedly fair assessment of equal employment opportunities (spoiler alert!), and we sort of... just roll with the punches in Africa.I enjoyed exploring this question with knowledgeable folks and wonderful community who shared their experiences with me, and pitched this story in the first place.Let's make Digital Nomads even better.I'm looking to explore more topical issues around housing, economy, and tech in African hubs and how nomads impact these different dimensions.Let's talk hashtag#Nomads; send a message.And oh—the answer to the question I opened with is more systemic and rather circumstantial than I'd imagined. What are the odds for Africans living and working from the continent?I talk about it here: https://lnkd.in/dRwmT3V7What's your experience with "location-adjusted" pay?

Java 24: More than an update — a powerful step forward for modern software architecture. hashtag#LinkedInInsiderBRWith the official release of Java 24, Oracle continues to evolve the platform in ways that directly support today's demands for scalability, modularity, and cloud-native design. For professionals like me who architect systems with Hexagonal Architecture (DDD) and deploy on AWS, this release brings substantial benefits.🚀 Key Features in Java 24:✅ JEP 447 – Statements before super(...) Allows initialization logic before calling the superclass constructor. This enhances flexibility in rich domain models and simplifies base-class inheritance patterns in DDD.✅ JEP 456 – Unnamed Variables and Patterns (Preview) Reduces boilerplate when using pattern matching, making business logic cleaner and more expressive.✅ JEP 459 – String Templates (Second Preview) Provides safe and efficient string interpolation — ideal for building dynamic responses, configurations, and messages without complex concatenation.✅ JEP 460 – Vector API (7th Incubator) Enables data-parallel operations for better performance in compute-heavy tasks — relevant for analytics or event-driven systems.✅ JEP 462 – Structured Concurrency (Second Preview) Improves thread lifecycle management and simplifies parallel processing. This is huge for backend services needing concurrency without chaos — perfect fit for services deployed via AWS Lambda, ECS, or EKS.🧱 How this strengthens Hexagonal Architecture and DDDJava 24’s cleaner syntax and enhanced language constructs allow for: 🔹 Richer domain modeling without ceremony 🔹 Easier testing and mocking of application ports 🔹 Clearer separation of concerns in inbound/outbound adapters 🔹 Better observability and tracing when paired with AWS services like CloudWatch & X-Ray☁️ AWS + Java 24 = Cloud-native powerCombined with AWS, Java 24 enables: ✅ Lighter Lambda functions (faster cold starts with JDK optimizations) ✅ Enhanced developer productivity with CodeWhisperer and Amazon Q Developer ✅ Seamless integration with infrastructure-as-code (CDK, Terraform) and microservices ecosystemsWe’re not just writing code — we’re building resilient, scalable ecosystems. Java 24 gives us sharper tools to do that smarter, faster, and cleaner.Are you already experimenting with Java 24? What’s your favorite improvement so far?hashtag#Java24 hashtag#HexagonalArchitecture hashtag#DDD hashtag#SoftwareArchitecture hashtag#AWS hashtag#CloudNative hashtag#Innovation hashtag#BackendEngineering hashtag#Leadership hashtag#LinkedInInsiderBR

Can you really get hired from anywhere in the world?As I learnt, it's one of the toughest questions to answer in the recruitment world. The details are fuzzy, bias is always seeping into the supposedly fair assessment of equal employment opportunities (spoiler alert!), and we sort of... just roll with the punches in Africa.I enjoyed exploring this question with knowledgeable folks and wonderful community who shared their experiences with me, and pitched this story in the first place.Let's make Digital Nomads even better.I'm looking to explore more topical issues around housing, economy, and tech in African hubs and how nomads impact these different dimensions.Let's talk hashtag#Nomads; send a message.And oh—the answer to the question I opened with is more systemic and rather circumstantial than I'd imagined. What are the odds for Africans living and working from the continent?I talk about it here: https://lnkd.in/dRwmT3V7What's your experience with "location-adjusted" pay?

Java 24: More than an update — a powerful step forward for modern software architecture. hashtag#LinkedInInsiderBRWith the official release of Java 24, Oracle continues to evolve the platform in ways that directly support today's demands for scalability, modularity, and cloud-native design. For professionals like me who architect systems with Hexagonal Architecture (DDD) and deploy on AWS, this release brings substantial benefits.🚀 Key Features in Java 24:✅ JEP 447 – Statements before super(...) Allows initialization logic before calling the superclass constructor. This enhances flexibility in rich domain models and simplifies base-class inheritance patterns in DDD.✅ JEP 456 – Unnamed Variables and Patterns (Preview) Reduces boilerplate when using pattern matching, making business logic cleaner and more expressive.✅ JEP 459 – String Templates (Second Preview) Provides safe and efficient string interpolation — ideal for building dynamic responses, configurations, and messages without complex concatenation.✅ JEP 460 – Vector API (7th Incubator) Enables data-parallel operations for better performance in compute-heavy tasks — relevant for analytics or event-driven systems.✅ JEP 462 – Structured Concurrency (Second Preview) Improves thread lifecycle management and simplifies parallel processing. This is huge for backend services needing concurrency without chaos — perfect fit for services deployed via AWS Lambda, ECS, or EKS.🧱 How this strengthens Hexagonal Architecture and DDDJava 24’s cleaner syntax and enhanced language constructs allow for: 🔹 Richer domain modeling without ceremony 🔹 Easier testing and mocking of application ports 🔹 Clearer separation of concerns in inbound/outbound adapters 🔹 Better observability and tracing when paired with AWS services like CloudWatch & X-Ray☁️ AWS + Java 24 = Cloud-native powerCombined with AWS, Java 24 enables: ✅ Lighter Lambda functions (faster cold starts with JDK optimizations) ✅ Enhanced developer productivity with CodeWhisperer and Amazon Q Developer ✅ Seamless integration with infrastructure-as-code (CDK, Terraform) and microservices ecosystemsWe’re not just writing code — we’re building resilient, scalable ecosystems. Java 24 gives us sharper tools to do that smarter, faster, and cleaner.Are you already experimenting with Java 24? What’s your favorite improvement so far?hashtag#Java24 hashtag#HexagonalArchitecture hashtag#DDD hashtag#SoftwareArchitecture hashtag#AWS hashtag#CloudNative hashtag#Innovation hashtag#BackendEngineering hashtag#Leadership hashtag#LinkedInInsiderBR

Java 24: More than an update — a powerful step forward for modern software architecture. hashtag#LinkedInInsiderBRWith the official release of Java 24, Oracle continues to evolve the platform in ways that directly support today's demands for scalability, modularity, and cloud-native design. For professionals like me who architect systems with Hexagonal Architecture (DDD) and deploy on AWS, this release brings substantial benefits.🚀 Key Features in Java 24:✅ JEP 447 – Statements before super(...) Allows initialization logic before calling the superclass constructor. This enhances flexibility in rich domain models and simplifies base-class inheritance patterns in DDD.✅ JEP 456 – Unnamed Variables and Patterns (Preview) Reduces boilerplate when using pattern matching, making business logic cleaner and more expressive.✅ JEP 459 – String Templates (Second Preview) Provides safe and efficient string interpolation — ideal for building dynamic responses, configurations, and messages without complex concatenation.✅ JEP 460 – Vector API (7th Incubator) Enables data-parallel operations for better performance in compute-heavy tasks — relevant for analytics or event-driven systems.✅ JEP 462 – Structured Concurrency (Second Preview) Improves thread lifecycle management and simplifies parallel processing. This is huge for backend services needing concurrency without chaos — perfect fit for services deployed via AWS Lambda, ECS, or EKS.🧱 How this strengthens Hexagonal Architecture and DDDJava 24’s cleaner syntax and enhanced language constructs allow for: 🔹 Richer domain modeling without ceremony 🔹 Easier testing and mocking of application ports 🔹 Clearer separation of concerns in inbound/outbound adapters 🔹 Better observability and tracing when paired with AWS services like CloudWatch & X-Ray☁️ AWS + Java 24 = Cloud-native powerCombined with AWS, Java 24 enables: ✅ Lighter Lambda functions (faster cold starts with JDK optimizations) ✅ Enhanced developer productivity with CodeWhisperer and Amazon Q Developer ✅ Seamless integration with infrastructure-as-code (CDK, Terraform) and microservices ecosystemsWe’re not just writing code — we’re building resilient, scalable ecosystems. Java 24 gives us sharper tools to do that smarter, faster, and cleaner.Are you already experimenting with Java 24? What’s your favorite improvement so far?hashtag#Java24 hashtag#HexagonalArchitecture hashtag#DDD hashtag#SoftwareArchitecture hashtag#AWS hashtag#CloudNative hashtag#Innovation hashtag#BackendEngineering hashtag#Leadership hashtag#LinkedInInsiderBR

Java 24: More than an update — a powerful step forward for modern software architecture. hashtag#LinkedInInsiderBRWith the official release of Java 24, Oracle continues to evolve the platform in ways that directly support today's demands for scalability, modularity, and cloud-native design. For professionals like me who architect systems with Hexagonal Architecture (DDD) and deploy on AWS, this release brings substantial benefits.🚀 Key Features in Java 24:✅ JEP 447 – Statements before super(...) Allows initialization logic before calling the superclass constructor. This enhances flexibility in rich domain models and simplifies base-class inheritance patterns in DDD.✅ JEP 456 – Unnamed Variables and Patterns (Preview) Reduces boilerplate when using pattern matching, making business logic cleaner and more expressive.✅ JEP 459 – String Templates (Second Preview) Provides safe and efficient string interpolation — ideal for building dynamic responses, configurations, and messages without complex concatenation.✅ JEP 460 – Vector API (7th Incubator) Enables data-parallel operations for better performance in compute-heavy tasks — relevant for analytics or event-driven systems.✅ JEP 462 – Structured Concurrency (Second Preview) Improves thread lifecycle management and simplifies parallel processing. This is huge for backend services needing concurrency without chaos — perfect fit for services deployed via AWS Lambda, ECS, or EKS.🧱 How this strengthens Hexagonal Architecture and DDDJava 24’s cleaner syntax and enhanced language constructs allow for: 🔹 Richer domain modeling without ceremony 🔹 Easier testing and mocking of application ports 🔹 Clearer separation of concerns in inbound/outbound adapters 🔹 Better observability and tracing when paired with AWS services like CloudWatch & X-Ray☁️ AWS + Java 24 = Cloud-native powerCombined with AWS, Java 24 enables: ✅ Lighter Lambda functions (faster cold starts with JDK optimizations) ✅ Enhanced developer productivity with CodeWhisperer and Amazon Q Developer ✅ Seamless integration with infrastructure-as-code (CDK, Terraform) and microservices ecosystemsWe’re not just writing code — we’re building resilient, scalable ecosystems. Java 24 gives us sharper tools to do that smarter, faster, and cleaner.Are you already experimenting with Java 24? What’s your favorite improvement so far?hashtag#Java24 hashtag#HexagonalArchitecture hashtag#DDD hashtag#SoftwareArchitecture hashtag#AWS hashtag#CloudNative hashtag#Innovation hashtag#BackendEngineering hashtag#Leadership hashtag#LinkedInInsiderBR

𝑻𝒉𝒆 𝑯𝒂𝒓𝒔𝒉 𝑹𝒆𝒂𝒍𝒊𝒕𝒚: 𝑹𝒆𝒎𝒐𝒕𝒆 𝑱𝒐𝒃 𝑺𝒊𝒕𝒆𝒔 𝑩𝒆𝒄𝒐𝒎𝒊𝒏𝒈 𝑼𝒏𝒓𝒆𝒂𝒄𝒉𝒂𝒃𝒍𝒆 𝒇𝒐𝒓 𝒕𝒉𝒆 𝑼𝒏𝒆𝒎𝒑𝒍𝒐𝒚𝒆𝒅As remote work grows, platforms like We Work Remotely, Remote OK, and FlexJobs and many companies  promise flexible employment opportunities. But many of these platforms require paid subscriptions to access job listings, creating a barrier for the unemployed, especially in developing countries.Imagine trying to apply for jobs when you can't even afford to unlock a post. It’s a harsh reality for those already struggling.𝑻𝒉𝒆 𝑰𝒓𝒐𝒏𝒚 𝒐𝒇 𝑨𝒄𝒄𝒆𝒔𝒔Remote work is supposed to be inclusive, yet paywalls create a digital divide. Those who can afford to pay get a chance, while those who can’t are locked out.𝑾𝒉𝒂𝒕 𝑵𝒆𝒆𝒅𝒔 𝒕𝒐 𝑪𝒉𝒂𝒏𝒈𝒆?𝑭𝒓𝒆𝒆𝒎𝒊𝒖𝒎 𝑴𝒐𝒅𝒆𝒍𝒔;Provide more real opportunities for free.𝑫𝒊𝒔𝒄𝒐𝒖𝒏𝒕𝒔 𝒇𝒐𝒓 𝒕𝒉𝒆 𝑼𝒏𝒆𝒎𝒑𝒍𝒐𝒚𝒆𝒅:Offer reduced or free access for those with limited income.𝑶𝒑𝒆𝒏 𝑷𝒍𝒂𝒕𝒇𝒐𝒓𝒎𝒔:More platforms should serve global job seekers without turning access into a commodity.𝑭𝒊𝒏𝒂𝒍 𝑻𝒉𝒐𝒖𝒈𝒉𝒕𝒔Remote work should be a right, not a luxury. Java 24: More than an update — a powerful step forward for modern software architecture. hashtag#LinkedInInsiderBRWith the official release of Java 24, Oracle continues to evolve the platform in ways that directly support today's demands for scalability, modularity, and cloud-native design. For professionals like me who architect systems with Hexagonal Architecture (DDD) and deploy on AWS, this release brings substantial benefits.🚀 Key Features in Java 24:✅ JEP 447 – Statements before super(...) Allows initialization logic before calling the superclass constructor. This enhances flexibility in rich domain models and simplifies base-class inheritance patterns in DDD.✅ JEP 456 – Unnamed Variables and Patterns (Preview) Reduces boilerplate when using pattern matching, making business logic cleaner and more expressive.✅ JEP 459 – String Templates (Second Preview) Provides safe and efficient string interpolation — ideal for building dynamic responses, configurations, and messages without complex concatenation.✅ JEP 460 – Vector API (7th Incubator) Enables data-parallel operations for better performance in compute-heavy tasks — relevant for analytics or event-driven systems.✅ JEP 462 – Structured Concurrency (Second Preview) Improves thread lifecycle management and simplifies parallel processing. This is huge for backend services needing concurrency without chaos — perfect fit for services deployed via AWS Lambda, ECS, or EKS.🧱 How this strengthens Hexagonal Architecture and DDDJava 24’s cleaner syntax and enhanced language constructs allow for: 🔹 Richer domain modeling without ceremony 🔹 Easier testing and mocking of application ports 🔹 Clearer separation of concerns in inbound/outbound adapters 🔹 Better observability and tracing when paired with AWS services like CloudWatch & X-Ray☁️ AWS + Java 24 = Cloud-native powerCombined with AWS, Java 24 enables: ✅ Lighter Lambda functions (faster cold starts with JDK optimizations) ✅ Enhanced developer productivity with CodeWhisperer and Amazon Q Developer ✅ Seamless integration with infrastructure-as-code (CDK, Terraform) and microservices ecosystemsWe’re not just writing code — we’re building resilient, scalable ecosystems. Java 24 gives us sharper tools to do that smarter, faster, and cleaner.Are you already experimenting with Java 24? What’s your favorite improvement so far?hashtag#Java24 hashtag#HexagonalArchitecture hashtag#DDD hashtag#SoftwareArchitecture hashtag#AWS hashtag#CloudNative hashtag#Innovation hashtag#BackendEngineering hashtag#Leadership hashtag#LinkedInInsiderBR

Can you really get hired from anywhere in the world?As I learnt, it's one of the toughest questions to answer in the recruitment world. The details are fuzzy, bias is always seeping into the supposedly fair assessment of equal employment opportunities (spoiler alert!), and we sort of... just roll with the punches in Africa.I enjoyed exploring this question with knowledgeable folks and wonderful community who shared their experiences with me, and pitched this story in the first place.Let's make Digital Nomads even better.I'm looking to explore more topical issues around housing, economy, and tech in African hubs and how nomads impact these different dimensions.Let's talk hashtag#Nomads; send a message.And oh—the answer to the question I opened with is more systemic and rather circumstantial than I'd imagined. What are the odds for Africans living and working from the continent?I talk about it here: https://lnkd.in/dRwmT3V7What's your experience with "location-adjusted" pay?

Java 24: More than an update — a powerful step forward for modern software architecture. hashtag#LinkedInInsiderBRWith the official release of Java 24, Oracle continues to evolve the platform in ways that directly support today's demands for scalability, modularity, and cloud-native design. For professionals like me who architect systems with Hexagonal Architecture (DDD) and deploy on AWS, this release brings substantial benefits.🚀 Key Features in Java 24:✅ JEP 447 – Statements before super(...) Allows initialization logic before calling the superclass constructor. This enhances flexibility in rich domain models and simplifies base-class inheritance patterns in DDD.✅ JEP 456 – Unnamed Variables and Patterns (Preview) Reduces boilerplate when using pattern matching, making business logic cleaner and more expressive.✅ JEP 459 – String Templates (Second Preview) Provides safe and efficient string interpolation — ideal for building dynamic responses, configurations, and messages without complex concatenation.✅ JEP 460 – Vector API (7th Incubator) Enables data-parallel operations for better performance in compute-heavy tasks — relevant for analytics or event-driven systems.✅ JEP 462 – Structured Concurrency (Second Preview) Improves thread lifecycle management and simplifies parallel processing. This is huge for backend services needing concurrency without chaos — perfect fit for services deployed via AWS Lambda, ECS, or EKS.🧱 How this strengthens Hexagonal Architecture and DDDJava 24’s cleaner syntax and enhanced language constructs allow for: 🔹 Richer domain modeling without ceremony 🔹 Easier testing and mocking of application ports 🔹 Clearer separation of concerns in inbound/outbound adapters 🔹 Better observability and tracing when paired with AWS services like CloudWatch & X-Ray☁️ AWS + Java 24 = Cloud-native powerCombined with AWS, Java 24 enables: ✅ Lighter Lambda functions (faster cold starts with JDK optimizations) ✅ Enhanced developer productivity with CodeWhisperer and Amazon Q Developer ✅ Seamless integration with infrastructure-as-code (CDK, Terraform) and microservices ecosystemsWe’re not just writing code — we’re building resilient, scalable ecosystems. Java 24 gives us sharper tools to do that smarter, faster, and cleaner.Are you already experimenting with Java 24? What’s your favorite improvement so far?hashtag#Java24 hashtag#HexagonalArchitecture hashtag#DDD hashtag#SoftwareArchitecture hashtag#AWS hashtag#CloudNative hashtag#Innovation hashtag#BackendEngineering hashtag#Leadership hashtag#LinkedInInsiderBR
